Huge flavor of bitter resinous hops balanced by lots of caramel bread malt flavors. Big booziness too, the warmth and bite of which last for quite a while. Really good - maybe the best of the bastard series, though the original is great too. Would definitely get again.

Wow, un grande bière! L’arôme fort du caramel, sucre brun, et l’alcool. Le goût est des fruits séchés, caramel, sucre brun avec une finition amer bien équilibré pour une bière tellement forte. Très puissante, une excellent bière d’hiver.

Bottle from Total Wine. Home snifter pour is dark orange brown and murky. Small head and no lacing. The aroma is serious heavy malts, leather, burnt caramel, kind of a swampy aroma as well. Taste is big malt bomb, dark fruits, dark breads, pine, wood, and earth.. Bitter pine finish. Thick oily mouth and an almost sticky finish.

650ml bottle of 2014 edition. Dark brown with one finger tan white head. Initial deep aroma of dried fruits, raisins and dates, and sweet syrup followed by increasing tones of piny hops. Sweet taste of dried fruits and sweet black bread (sirapslimpa) followed by bitter piny hops and then finishing sweet again with an almost desert wine character as well as some almost burnt roasted flavors. Probably medium thickness to the mouthfeel and medium carbonation with very well hidden alcohol.

Growler 2L btl.
Looks..Rick dark mahogany, med head.
Smells.. Big sticky boozy stonefruits, thigh rich caramel, sweet.
Tastes..chewy thick booze soaked hoppy stonefruits, liqueur-esque caramel.. definite alcohol, some warming heat and real bitterness muscle.

(650ml 2014 bottle @ Systembolaget) Pours clear copper with a small head of fine off white bubbles that lingers with no lace. Aroma quite malty, toffee and caramel, touch of fig pudding, marmalade hop character, pine, smells like a barley wine. Palate rich, quite sweet at first with a fair bit of bitterness, toffee, marmalade, a little dried fruit. Hops show up a lot more in the middle of the palate, lots of pine needle and resin as the bitterness takes hold. Malt core holds all the way through to the aftertaste but the bitterness is quite high by the finish, astringent, mostly pine/resin with some candied orange. Lots of hops in the aftertaste. Fairly full and oily in the mouth, very soft carb, a bit of alcohol heat. I would definitely call this an American barley wine. It’s a really good one though, nice balance, smooth and malty with enough to hold the big hop character later on in the sip.

Aroma is roasted malts, honey and caramel. Taste is all sorts of great deep malts, raisins and caramel. Thick almost chewy mouthfeel. Light creaminess and a very well balanced hop profile that is earthy and has slight clove and lemon grass notes. Appearance is a clear copper body with a medium pearl head that retains well.

2014 version, which is 11%, from Favourite Beer, Cheltenham. Deep amber colour with a beige head. Burnt caramel, malts, marmalade and alcohol aroma. Well balanced bitter sweet start with a bitter finish. Very thick palate. Love it!

On tap at Nakameguro Taproom. Served in a snifter. Deep amber color with a huge pink soapy head. Slight malt aroma with a bit of sourness present. Sweetness present on the palate from the malts with a hint of bitterness and a strong bit of alcohol present. Oily mouthfeel with a nice long smooth finish. Solid strong ale.

Medium chocolate brown, moderate foam. Caramel malt aroma with some hops, smells strong, nothing special tbh. Hop characteristic is much stronger in the flavor, spruce, tiny bit of roastiness. Bitterness lingers nicely.
Draft. Dark amber brown with small tan head. Malty caramel atoms. Big malty version of bastard. Bitterness still shine through the extra malty palette. Delicious as expected.

Good beer. Slightly more bitter and less floral or citrus than I normally like for an ipa. Worth a try for big beer lovers but won't be a regular purchase for me. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

650ml brown bottle. 2013 release. Orange coloured, hazy, some floaties in later pours. Small cap of creamy beige foam. Nose has toffee malts, mild citrus and alcohol. Taste has caramel and toffee sweetness, late hop bitterness and some alcohol. Full bodied with softer mouthfeel. Strong, rich, boozy, hoppy - all things I enjoy. Seems like a great beer to pull out on a cold winter’s night, one to sip slowly.

1pt bottle. Pours a lovely ruby red, very little head. Sweet and malty arome with some dark fruit. Flavour has the same, along with some fierce bitterness to balance it out. Definitely more of a barley wine than anything else. Any way, a beast of a beer.

This is pretty much a barleywine... The fact that they don’t call it a barleywine is just a testimate to just how many f*cks stone does not give. It’s both sweet and deliciously malty and brutally hoppy... It’s pretty much everything all at the same time, but it isn’t all confused tasting..... If it were a barleywine it would be my favorite barleywine, but as it stands it’ll just be my favorite "strong ale" whatever in the hell that’s supposed to be...
Very good. Very malty. Almost like a barely wine. Probably one of my favorite strong ales.

Bottled 10/16/14. Pours a hazy chestnut color with a thick cream-colored head. Aroma is malt, honey, fig, toffee, and notable hops in the background. Flavor is caramel, toffee, little bit of fig, and a nice long hoppy finish. Drinks a lot like a Barleywine. Wow this is phenomenal. Way better than the regular arrogant bastard.

Bottle from cellar stash sale at Corvallis Brew & Supply. 2008 vintage.A: Mahogany color with a foamy creme color head. Legs.N: Pine, licorice, star anise, toffee, leather and tobacco, some hop residuals - mostly pineapple, earth and peppercorn. Raisin, fig, woodiness, clove. T: Gigantic bitterness and sweetness. M: Medium body, fuzzy carbonation, alcohol is restrained actually. Much different than the fresh bottles I have had.O: An assertive beer. Fresh, it?s a bit of a hoppy, alcoholic mess, but at 6 years old, it?s like a bigger Bigfoot. Almost an exact comp, actually

660ml bottle (BierKompass.de) 2012 release, drunk 2015/01

Very nice barley wine aroma, sweet caramelly malts. Perfumey, but nice. Full smooth sweet palate. Massive malty palate. Nice bitter hops. Dang, this is a good barleywine. Love the balance of the hops and the malts, both components are very assertive, but not over-the-top. Drying palate makes me thirsty for more, which is a good sign.

660ml bottle (thanks FatPhil). Hazy dark copper color. Medium size, yellow head, stays. Sweet, malty, citrus, raisins, mild alcohol in aroma. Caramel, raisins, plum stones, chocolate, malts in taste. Slight fizzy carbonation which adds character to that beer. Sweet malty aftertaste. Spicy hops hopping on my tongue in aftertaste. Beautiful. Where is that 11% of alcohol? Nowhere! Fantastic!

2005 at Monkey Paw. Pours hazy reddish brown with a thin, fizzy off white head. Tastes like rich raisin, booze, and very sweet malt. Medium body and low carbonation. Smells like alcohol, woody, and sugary sweet malt, very faint hops.

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a snifter. A - Woah! Big aromas in this beer. Smells very floral and boozy. Plenty of hop bitterness present as well A - Deep amber hue--just a tad darker than the standard ABA. The lightly tanned head receded down to a thin layer of bubbles that hung out atop the brew throughout the drink. T - The attack features an array of floral notes and plenty of malty sweetness which continues through the middle of the sip. The finish features that Stone signature blast of bitter which crescendos until it comes full circle and returns to the malty and caramely sweetness. Wow. P - Such a full and rich mouthfeel. I can feel my tongue counting up the calories. The bitter finish cuts right through the richness and gives it a nice balance. O - This is a BIG beer. Very full in maltiness and extremely bitter. But it, no doubt, creates an amazing drinking experience. This beer has such large range of flavors and aromas: malty, floral, bitter, and boozy. It is extraordinarily balanced for such an intense drink. Beers this bitter may not be for everyone, but i couldn’t recommend it more. This is a supreme brew.

"Never turn your back on your beer."

2014 - 11% ABV. Pours a nice dark reddish amber brown with a weak head. Aroma is fruity, apricot, hoppy, caramel, oak, wood, boozey, spice, malt richness. Taste is caramel, cereal, biscuit, oak, vanilla, malt, spice, boozy, with a bitter finish. Overall a very good beer, not huge considering the 11%, very good.
Growler from Big Hops. Deep reddish amber color, minimal head. Aroma is a little boozy, malty, not especially hoppy. A bit woody, smooth, good all around strong ale.

Aroma - a touch of oak along with the malt? A touch of caramel. Hops are staying in the background. Some alcohol though not as prominent as I would expect given the ABV.

Appearance- a fairly dark copper with very little head. Pretty clear. Mild to moderate carbonation.

Taste- not as sweet as I would expect given the ABV. Some fairly distinct bitterness.

Palate - medium to full body, finish has that wood flavor on it.

Overall a good enjoyable beer. Not quite complex enough to be a great beer.

Dark malts and caramel for aroma. Pretty bitter bite than increases and then starts to calm on the palate. Leaves a bitter taste in the back of your mouth. I would get it again although, at 11.2%, I wouldn't have too many ;)

Bitter brew shared by Blake J. at World of Beer in Baltimore, for his 1000th beer club selection. This was an awesome brew. Semi-sweet and hints of herbs with a hoppy element that lingers on the after-taste. The amber colored brew was ok.
5 years old, from the cellar. Comparable to the Arrogant Bastard, but with more malt and less hops. Could be the cellaring.
Nice deep red pour. Toffee, caramel, and nice toasted malt notes on the nose and palate.

12/30/14. 2014 bomber. Not much to add to the other notes. Definitely a bit boozy and warm with deep hop and spice notes.

The aroma off this double bastard was of strong alcohol with notes of oak, smoke and whiskey barrels. It poured beautifully with an amazing dark red amber. There were strong notes of caramel, leather, whiskey, charred oak, and something sweet that I cannot describe. The finish was just as complex as the start, warm and with strong alcohol fumes.

Pouring a deep and rich amber colour with a clear, sparkly body and a thin beige head that clings to the glass. The aroma is heavy and rich with loads of toffee and caramel malts atop surprisingly sweet and fruity aromas of orange peel and citrus. A bit of spice and bready malts pervade that aroma. The first sip is overly sweet and sugary with toffee and caramel malts, notes of nuts, pine and citrus hop notes and raisin. Towards the finish the fruit notes peter out leaving more hop emphasis with pine and grapefruit resin notes. Alot of biscuity and bready malts leave a rather heavy mouthfeel that comes across a bit oily and thick. The finish is dry and moderately astringent with a surprising smoothness. The alcohol is well hidden but for a slight warmth on the finish.
Huge beer for sure, taste better as it warms. Drinks easy for 11+ abv but still get the alcohol. Worth a try but not something for the normal rotation. Take your time drinking this one.

66cl. Bottle. 2013 Release. Bottled on 2013-10-08 

Pours dark amber with off white head. 

Aroma caramel, toffee, pine, citrus, orange, brown sugar, roasted malts, dark and red fruits, bit of spice, biscuit. 

Taste caramel toffee loads of fruits sweet, piney citrus roasty bitter. 

Mouthfeel oily feel, sticky, soft carbonation. 

This is awesome, complex aroma and taste. Love it.
22 FL OZ ($5.99) had the 2014 release, it was damn good. 11% and does not even feel a bit over 6.5%. great beer and will buy again

Had on tap at the Grog. $6 for the full pint. Pours a murky rust reddish brown. Aromas of wet cardboard, grilled corn, strawberry concentrate, DME, flaked barley, mildew, unripe limes, and sweat. Taste the same with the addition of plastic-flavored hops, cabbage, stale orange juice. Extraordinarily bitter at bitter. Strangely fruit-forward, as well. Meh. Not for me.

Bottle: 2010 vintage. A little older than four years. Beaming, semi-cloudy copper body with a lovely, frothy beige head. Nice carbonation, good sign. Aroma has a huge, sticky caramel & toffee profile. Some light earthiness, the hops are still alive a bit, it seems. Faint notes of chocolate truffle, toast, & pine oil. Flavor is like caramel coated hops. Still plenty of earthy, leafy bitterness but with the malt backbone of an elephant. Sticky sweet toffee, light cocoa powder, & a hint of metallic saltiness towards the finish. Lasting pine bitterness with some residual, sticky caramel that coats the palate. No signs of oxidation yet. Heavy, sticky body. Enjoyable, clearly it has held up pretty well for the last four years or so.

Bomber. Wonderful dark fruit and caramel malt aroma with light alcohol notes as well as some grapefruit citrus hops. Pours dark amber with a thin light brown head and minimal lacing. Starts with sweet dark fruit and caramel. Finishes dry but smooth with just a touch of grapefruit citrus hoppiness. Excellent west coast barleywine!

Poured into tulip a reddy dark Amber with Amber head that receded to sides of glass quickly. Limited lacing. Aroma was complex as was the taste. Grapefruit over malt with dark fruits some spice. Just a lot here, this is amazing. Alcohol is hidden mouthfeel is oily. Wonderful.

22 ounce bottle into tulip glass; 2013 vintage, bottled on 9/16/2013. Pours slightly hazy deep ruby red color with a 2 finger dense and fluffy light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass. Aromas of big grapefruit, orange zest, pineapple, pine, raisin, plum, caramel, toffee, toast, brown sugar, biscuit, light nuttiness, floral, grass, and floral/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of citrus/pine hops and dark/bready malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big grapefruit, orange zest, pineapple, pine, raisin, plum, caramel, toffee, toast, brown sugar, biscuit, light nuttiness, floral, grass, and floral/toasted earthiness. Good amount of pine/grassy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, orange zest, pineapple, pine, raisin, plum, caramel, toffee, toast, brown sugar, biscuit, light nuttiness, and floral/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/pine hops and dark/bready malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a smooth and moderately creamy/sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is an awesome strong ale style. All around great robustness, complexity, and balance of citrus/pine hops and dark/bready malt flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the big ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

Aroma of hops and some malty yeastiness. Pours a rich amber with a gorgeous foamy head. Taste of hops, bitter pine, dark fruits, malts, resin, etc. A huge beer with tons of complex flavours. 

(And although the Stone Rep in AB refused to disclose the IBUs for this, I’d guess between 80-95)! ;)

650ml bottle pours black in color with a 2 finger white head that leaves some decent lacing on the glass. Aroma is dark fruits, chocolate and roasted grains. Taste is a dark fruit and chocolate malty sweetness with a grainy and dark fruity sweetness. This brew is much more complicated than I can describe here. Overall, this is an outstanding brew, full bodied with nice carbonation, well balanced and only for serious beer lovers out there.

Bottle, body the color of new mahogany, skiff of foam, fades pretty quickly. Aroma is malty caramel, raisin, some spruce. Taste is sweet and sharp, malt and spruce and spice, orange/lychee, with citrus rind bitter. Palate is smooth and rich, not overly thick, with fine moderate carbonation.finish is bitter sweet, but leaving an almost astringent bitter taste that lingers too long to be pleasant. Guess I have to keep drinking it.

A fantastic beer, so complex. The aroma is sweet and malty , the initial taste is a sweet brown ale, but then come a flood of hops to dry the finish, making this a double bastard of an easy drinking 11% beer.
Draft. Brown with a big white head. Not much nose. Big full flavors of chocolate malts. Alcohol well hidden. Well made.

Seems I’ve sort of moves away from the arrogant bastard flavor lately. Maybe because it’s cold? Very strong beer. It really tastes like arrogant basyard with more octane , but the base flavors aren’t much stronger to compensate for higher abv. Bitterness is strong though abd it actually is more potent but not better than normal ab

Smells of malt and bubble gum, not bad. Good dark amber copper color with a little beige head and no lacing. Tastes sweet malt and bubble gum. A nice beer.

This one is very hefty. Good notes of caramel and oak. Definitely a sipper. Was a little disappointed with this one.
Pretty brown Orange with khaki head. Pine, fruit, wood. Malt, caramel, more wood and pine in taste. Slightly sweet and boozy. Nice bitter and floral finish. Good stuff.

650 ml bottle  Pours a clear mahogany with moderate head. Aromas of dark sweet fruit, toffee, and sweet malts. Flavors are same with a big dose of bitter dry fruity hops. Good but still over rated.

Bottle: Thanks Hackobock: Served in a shaker:
Medium sized creamy head. Almost clear amber body.
Aroma is a delicious mix of hops, yeast, wood, toast, some fruits, some herbs deliciously balanced.
Flavour has tones of bread, toast, bitters, malts, herbs, some caramel, dried leaves, hay/grass tints and some spice/alcohol.
Aftertaste is strong bitter with malts, some caramel, herbal toast, dried leaves and hay/grass.
Low carbo, creamy mouthfeel, full bodied and a creamy sticky texture.
Touch of alcohol, nonetheless great beer and quite an easy drinker for 11.2%ABV.

I poured a 22oz bottle into a tulip glass. It was dated as a 2010 release and cost $6.99 ($0.32 per ounce).



Appearance: An ugly rusty brown/brick red hue over a completely opaque body. Pours to a three-finger, ivory, frothy head which laces and retains very well.



Smell: Extremely sweet aroma of confectionery flavors and some alcohol.



Taste: I’ve never been a big fan of Stone’s “Bastard” series, as I tend to find them too abrasive for their own good (except Oaked Arrogant Bastard, which is perfectly balanced). Double Bastard tends to be the beefiest of them all, not surprisingly. I set this bottle aside in the basement nearly four years ago and had forgotten about until recently. With some age on it, this beer has become quite different from the hop bomb I remember. It’s very sweet, but not cloying, and is now well-balanced since the hops have faded.



If I were drinking this blind I could confuse it for a strong English-style barleywine. Huge confectionery notes are present right off the rip: toffee, caramel, peanut brittle, and butterscotch. Additional complexity through the middle with notes of red and black cherries. The hops still maintain some bitterness, but are not nearly as dry and astringent as they are fresh. Slight earthy/smoky/piney flavors through the middle with just a touch of bitterness. It finishes as it starts, but with some warming (and complementary) alcohol flavor and sensation. Overall, it’s a delectable beer, though not quite a mind-blower.



Drinkability: One of the reasons I’m not a fan of fresh Double Bastard is because it’s difficult to drink it in anything bigger than a tiny sip. With four years of age under its belt, it’s a different world. The mouthfeel is thick, calm, soft and smooth. The alcohol is subtle and leaves a gentle warming sensation. There’s a residual aftertaste of malty sweetness and minor dry bitterness, but it’s easily tolerable. Even at 11.2% ABV, this is no longer a beastly brew and I can handle the entire 22oz bomber myself.

2013 Bottling. Another night, another Rocky Patel Edge Lite and now a Double AB added to the equation. Pour is a thick dark amber with a thin ring of suds that stick to the goblet as I sip. Malt and slight orange peel aroma - nice! Alcohol not as forward as one would expect for an 11.2. Lingering bitter finish. Just reward after an out-n-back overnight backack/camping trip. 2013 bottling
Aroma: Thick dried fruit, plums, raisins, slight caramel.
Appearance: Deep cherry amber. Very little head. Tiny bubbled lacing that’s edging towards brandy.
Taste: Dried fruits, lots of sweetness to go with the alcohol, some piney hops, caramel. Every sip seems to reveal another layer. Cherries slipping into the picture now.
Palate: Medium/full body, carbonation is more lively in the mouth than the glass. Starts off syrupy/stick and then slightly dry finish that bitters.
Overall: This is a world tour of flavor and aroma. It really hides the abv well. I may prefer the oaked version for a more regular occasion, but this really knocks my socks off. Outstanding.

This is such a badass beer. To me this tastes pretty much the same as Arrogant Bastard, just with more alcohol and perhaps a bit more character. I appreciate its complexity and its brazen character, but I can’t say I really enjoy drinking it. But at the same time hell yeah I’d drink it again.

Stone’s Bastard releases never fail to blow my mind. For me, Double Bastard proved to be every bit as enjoyable as the other releases that I’ve, well, enjoyed (Arrogant Bastard and Oaked Arrogant Bastard). The malty caramel note that this brew starts off with is sublime. The spicy, herbal hop kick that comes after that is even better. Did I say better than sublime? I suppose that doesn’t make much sense. Yet, I do indeed consider Double Bastard to be twice as good as Arrogant Bastard. Admittedly, that’s a paradox. I consider Arrogant Bastard to be perfect. How can something be two times more perfect? Exactly. Infinity times two still equals infinity. That’s the nature of the Bastard series. Every beer is better than the last... even though the last one was perfect. Shit, maybe I shouldn’t drink so much before I post these reviews... Anyway, Double Bastard has a gorgeous amber-red color with a lovely off-white head. Aroma has boozy sweetness, dark fruits, and pungent hops. My bomber was bottled on 9/01/2013 which meant I was a mere 2 months and 1 day away from a year-old bottle. Oh well. The hops were still plenty aggressive but a bit refined. One thing’s for damn sure: the body was thick and the mouthfeel was warming in the best possible way. Okay, so I guess that was actually two things. Sue me. At the end of my tasting, I couldn’t find any gripes with this beer. I also fully enjoyed reading the bottle notes. Any brewery that uses the word "masturbatory" when talking about their ale is okay by me. Double Bastard made my night by giving me balls-out flavor with a healthy dose of class. I wouldn’t expect anything less than that from Stone.

Pours a deep amber color with off-white head. Caramel malts, floral notes, and some citrus on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with more malt.

Transfer from BA reviewed on 6-3-12- 
Poured from 22 oz bomber into snifter

Appearance –Pours a hazy brown mahogany color with a small off white head. The head fades fast to leave a very persistent white foam film on the top of the brew. 

Smell – A bready base aroma is mixed with huge hop aromas. There are big smells of bitter-resinous pine and citrus hop with other aromas of earthy nature. Mixed with all these are lighter fruit aromas and a good bit of alcohol aroma as well; rounding out the aroma profile well.

Taste – Throughout the taste there is a massive bready malt flavor. There is a light amount of caramel and light fruit sweetness at first mixed with a citrus hop flavor. The hop flavors at the beginning, while average for an IPA, then really start to gain strength. Citrus and pine hops start getting strong and start to bring some bitterness. The caramel sweetness is largely lost, but the citrus is still there. While the pine and citrus get stronger, they get huge and other hop flavors of a resinous earthy taste come to the tongue. All the hop flavors mix quite well and take the taste to the end, where they are greeted with a warming and lightly burning alcohol flavor, which oddly in some ways complements the hop quite well.

Mouthfeel –The body of the beer is creamy and chewy with all those flavors really coating the mouth in all the wonderful flavors. The lower carbonation only accentuates the creaminess with it also accentuating the hop and booze burn as well.

Overall – Very heavy and tasty. Its mouthfeel is fantastic and it has a nice blend of hop and booze taste. A great brew for sipping nice and slow.

22 oz. bottle aged two years. Deep amber color with still a nice level of carbonation. Aroma still shows a good hop presence, floral and fruit. Malt is here for sure as well, caramel and thick toffee.


The flavor still displays the hop presence as well, the signature Stone pine hop shows in the finish of the beer with the toffee, caramel and hints of dough. The ABV has mellowed out a bit and shows just a slight warming after the sip. With the age, the flavor has the malt taking over with the hops now complimenting the beer with a nice balance. Nice drink.

22oz bottle poured into a Stone specialty IPA glass (a hybrid between a flute and snifter). Where to start with the nose on this one ... well, I guess, at the start. The first aromas I picked up were that of vanilla and caramel primarily. After a little bit, some dark berry aromas start coming through followed shortly thereafter by a hint of nuts, figs, and plums. There’s also some licorice tucked away in there. The next round of aromas had a bit of a musty and damp smell to it, but it was also accompanied by a hint of pine, wood, and honey. By the end of the drink, I was also picking up citrus, cuacao, as well as banana & clove notes. It pours a clear honey orange color with a thick, beige, sudsy head that’s in no rush to recede. A healthy, rocky lacing is left behind on the glass. A medium-high bitter (fairly moderate by Stone standards) combines with a medium malty sweetness. This full bodied beer is creamy going down; aided by an abundant, yet mellow and soft carbonation. The malty front end is a toasted caramel and roasted nut flavor with some hints of dark, meaty fruits (figs / plums). Mid mid drink, this also takes on a woodsy quality as well. Notes of pine, resin, and citrus combine for a full, but mellow bitter finish with a nice touch of bourbon-caramel alcohol warmth; it a mildly dry finish  The aftertaste left behind is a balanced blend of smokey caramel, grapefruit, and resin with a touch of licorice.

From the giant bottle! Poured into a shaker. Ruby colored with a tan head. Aroma is pretty much all malt with a little bit of earthiness. Flavor starts off malt forward with sweeter notes like a red, but finishes with some earthy and piney hop notes. Fairly creamy and smooth for the ABV. Overall this reads like a nicely balanced strong red ale.

Poured from the 3l 2013 release. Very creamy thick head. Aroma has a nice balance of malty and hoppy. The malt character is biscuit y. It tastes like red malt s were used. The hops are a nice blend of slightly citrus but mostly dank and bitter! It’s bitter and I love it!

Pours a unique reddish brown color with some sediment. Has more head than I was expecting for 11.2% ABV, but it recedes quickly. Great looking beer. Smells strongly of alcohol, more of a sweet stout or barleywine smell than an ale. The aroma and appearance are near opposites of one another. Taste is hops up front, alcohol in the finish - that’s it. Not much of a malt presence that I could detect. Mouthfeel was fairly smooth for such a strong beer, but the aftertaste is way too boozy. You couldn’t eat anything with this beer; it would dominate the taste of any food. I was hoping for something more complex. I’m a big Stone fan, but I would recommend just about any of their IPA’s or stouts over this one. This beer is good for getting drunk (which does have it’s place), not for savoring.

This vicious brew punched me in the mouth and offered no apologies. Appearance is amber in color, bordering on dark brown. Whatever head there was quickly dissipated and left off white lacing on the sides of the glass as it was carefully consumed. It’s significantly more aggressive than say it’s more timid associate (Arrogant Bastard), thanks to the elevated alcohol content. Weighing in at a healthy 11.2 percent it could be used in a pinch to power lawn equipment or remove rust. Though the intense flavor and backdrop does an adequate job disguising the elevated ABV. In my opinion the Double Bastard seems to have ironed out all the perceived shortcomings of Arrogant Bastard Ale however insignificant and delusional as they may be. The taste is well balanced for something as visceral as it is. The taste lies somewhere between being to hoppy and being overly malty. Flavors are reminiscent of roast caramel, heavy malts and rich aged leather, all accompanied by a steady backbeat of bitter and aromatic hops. As far as I’m concerned Stone can do no wrong. This is a tasty beer meant to be enjoyed on a crisp winter evening accompanied by the warm harmony of a fire… or as a sleep aid. All joking aside, it’s a very good beer.

Pours a deep amber with a little off-white head and average lacing. Aroma is sweet with hints of dark fruits, toffee, vanilla, oak and a little brown sugar. Taste follows the nose with a mixture of everything from the aroma initially but then the hops try to shine through but it is a futile attempt. The malt is running the show here but that is to be expected with such a high abv. Medium to full bodied with low to moderate carbonation and a somewhat dry finish. Alcohol is noticeable but not in an off putting way. Having said that, be careful because this beer packs one hell of a punch. Next on the agenda is a growler of Stone’s Espresso Imperial Russian Stout so my liver is going to take a beating.

22oz bottle dated 9-26-2013, just over 4 months old, aged at cellar temp as instructed by the bottle. Pours a clear reddish amber with lasting foamy head and great lacing. Hops and alcohol burn mildly in the end. Ends bitter and dry. I have been burned by over-aged beers that turn into malt bombs and this is leaning towards that side of the taste spectrum. I suspect fresh this would be much better. Alcohol is appropriately evident for the ABV, with a mild burn and taste.

22 oz bottled over 4 months ago from Evergreen Discount into my NBB globe glass. Dark amber-reddish and hazy appearance with a large, light tan head, slowly diminishing, moderate lacing. 22oz bomber poured into a pint glass. Appearance is clear, dark amber with a modest two-finger cream-colored head that settles to a thin ring. Some lacing, which was surprising considering the ABV. Aroma suggests barleywine with lots of sweet caramel, brown sugar, alcohol, pine, cherries, and orange peel. Taste is a two-pronged all-out assault from sweetness and bitterness. Lots of caramel sweetness with dried fruit and orange. Bitterness features pine and floral notes. Alcohol is prominent, too, but complimentary not derailing. Full body, sticky, chewy texture, softer carbonation, bitter and warming on the finish, plus drier than expected for a high gravity beer.

22oz bottle into tulip. Minneapolis. Bottled 09.06.2013

Appearance: red/copper in color. mostly clear with a slight haze. Small tan head.

Aroma: Caramel and brown sugar is most present. Citrus and floral hop notes  back it up. Slight alcohol. 

Taste: Sweet at first, but evolves into a bitter, long lasting finish. The bitterness builds as you continue to drink the bottle.

Palate: A full body and mouthfeel. Light carbonation. Long bitter finish. 

Overall: Strong ale indeed. Nothing subtle about this beer. The flavors are upfront and intense. More bitter than I expected, but still very nice. For me this beer is less about complexity, and more about straight forward, strong flavor.

Appearance: deep clear amber with a silky, creamy, dense, near white head, poured into a snifter. Aroma: caramel and roasted nuts, toffee, plums in syrup, a hint of woody booze	.  Taste: brown sugar, raisin, caramel, candied nuts, a big wash of resinous, piney hops toward the back end.  Finish: slowly building boozy warmth grows over a lingering malty caramel and brown sugar thread, balanced by the lingering hoppy dryness. Notes: Definitely a big, strong ale, but it maintained a good semblance of balance and was surprisingly drinkable for an 11.2% beer--the alcohol was reasonably well-hidden.  Beerdvent 2013, day seven.

Bottle pour dark amber copper. Nose sweet malt, dank hop. Hint of earthy spice. Taste sweet malt, spicy hop. Bitter starts in mid palate and lasts through a long finish. Reasonable mouth feel. I once drank a 3L of this for New Years.

Draft at jungle jims: pours a dark, orangish red color with a healthy tan head. Aroma is toffee and pine needles... You know it’ll be bitter before you try it. Taste is a bit of caramel and sweetness, but that gets knocked out by the bracing piney bitterness. Lovely.

Deep copper, very yeasty, no head, strong lacing, sweet, flowers and alcoholic, candy sugar, intensely sweet on the palate with a long lingering harsh and strong bitterness, almost medical in its bitterness

A 3rd of a pint in Brewdog Glasgow (£4.25):


An alright beer at best and I felt that the beer was only about loading the flavour with a mix of hops and alcohol meaning the balance was poor and the beer was a hard on to drink with everything in your face and to the extreme. I’m glad I got to try this one but I don’t think I’ll be giving it a go again.

Bottle into snifter. Dark red color, dense small head. Aroma is toasty, resin, earthy, caramel, honey, banana. Flavor is powerful, with plenty of hops, roasted coffee caramel. Full bodied, sticky, lots of carbonation, extra bitter finish. Doesn’t live up to the diatribe on the back of the bottle, but pretty good.
Keg at Brewdog Brum. Nice lacing. Big, rich flavour, my old beauty. But pointy and glassy, like a posh Christmas tree decoration. Obviously lovely.

Wunderschöne farbe, bernstein, feine weisse schaumkrone, malzig fruchtig und etwas hopfiges aroma, sehr gehaltvolles mundgefühl, malzig und leicht alkoholisch im geschmack, stark gehopft, bitterer abgang welcher lange anhält

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Good beer. Honestly reminds me a lot of regular arrogant bastard. Another solid creation from stone.

Keg at Brewdog Edinburgh.Pours dark hazy orange. Nice head. The aroma is rich citrus hoppiness with sweet malts. And yes this is hoppy and bitter. That said, comparing this with many contemporary west coast US style ales, not so unusual these days... actually nae, This is one rich hoppy bastard ! What I particularly like about this is the way that the relatively massive hop bitterness doesn’t in any way derail the wonderful malts and hop flovours. It just works. They got this spot on, as they did with Arrogant. Had this a few times now and certainly will again.

Pours burnt orange with some red flames amongst it. Large, impressive robust tan head - its like bubble-bath foam on bath water.
Heavy hoppy aroma. Bitterness is invasive even in the aroma. Some toffee malt, heavily piney. Reminiscent of an even more brutal American DIPA. 
Heavy and strong mouth-feel. I should have worked out my jaw before chugging. Hop-forward pine strangles the wimpy citrus. Heavy sugary malt. Some caramelised fruit. Consuming, evolving and evolving bitterness. Wow, that has pummeled my taste buds. Does it NEED to be this bitter? No-one enjoys a mouthful of flies, surely?
HOPS! Fancy meeting you here in such a lovely cold bottle. Every time I drink this beer, my poor taste buds feel like they’re being brutalized, and that is NOT a bad thing.
Bottle from Binnys. Poured amber with yellowish head that hangs. Aroma of pine and malt. Stings. Quite smooth med body. Slight bitter taste thats pleasant.

On tap at Prefunk, 2013 version. Dark brown with small foamy beige head. Aroma is nutty, roast grains, some alcohol warmth plays out in the nose. Flavor is strong, sharp hop bitterness, heavy malt, tingly palate and plenty more alcohol warmth. A real winter warmer.

Vintage 2012, 
Pours copper, light tan central dome and rim with some confluent etching. Smells of alcohol, hops (weed, resin, grapefruit and some tea) plenty of crystal malts, some more tea some more booze, a bit of nougat and vanilla and banana. Flavor is bitter, boozy and sweet. Lots of malt, lots of bittering hops, plenty of alcohol character. Medium bodied with moderate carb. I don’t think I care for this fresh. Not at all.

vintage 2010- 15AUG11 - 2/4/3.5/3.5/4-3.63
A: Pours a turbid copper ale with less than a single finger of light peanut foam. This dissipates rather quickly to a mirror surface and a central cap of foam. No lacing. Surprised at how turbid this is.
S: Caramel malts, toffee, richly blended. Really nice smell, and for some reason, when I take a good long hit of this, I get candied and mulled orange smells. I dig it. Reminds me of a well aged barley wine.
T: Sweet and bready with a midline transition highlighting the alpha acid in here. Then an additional mutation to a slightly oxidized and metallic grain bed. Above average for sure.
M: Medium on heavy for the style with moderate to lo carb. Transient slick on the palate falls dry at the end.
O: Good beer. Look foward to reviewing fresh.

Serving type: bottle

11-11-2012

on tap at the Provisions market, grapefruit nose with some hops, tasty hoppy beer but nothing too aggressive not the biggest fan of this marketing campaign but whatever floats Stones boat. The alcohol is well hidden tho

Catch up rating #godknowswhat @Tria, Washington Sq, PHL 30/11/13 - last beer of this particular stateside trip !
Keg - dark amber with a big ole light beige head dress.
Nose is candied sugars, red grapefruit, toffee, brown sugars, bitter candied orange peel. hint of liqourice.
Taste comprises bitter citrics, candy sugar, grapefruit peel, rich caramel vein running throughout, orange pith, darker warming fruit notes.
Full end of medium bodied, fine carbonation, sweet finale, slightly drying.
Decent American strong - the alcohol is pretty well integrated for a double digit monster !

Draft at bistro on bridge. Pours clear amber with a medium sized off white head. The aroma is very hoppy. There is earthiness, grapefruit, and some caramel malt. The taste has a huge bitter hoppy kick followed by an amazing many sweet caramel balance. Terrific balance and alcohol is hidden well.

2013/12/01 - Pours a clear, dark, burnt amber colour with a thick, fluffy, khaki head. Tons of lacing. Aroma is grapefruit, citrus, pine, hop resin and wood. Taste is citrus hops, malt caramel backbone, pine, wood and alcohol. Thick oily mouthfeel with smooth carbonation and a slight boozy, warming finish. Caramel backbone and alcohol really balance out the citrus and pine hop flavours. A big beer that is amazingly well balanced. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clear amber ale with a medium foamy off-white head. The nose is resiny with some grapefruit and floral pine, and a touch of oak. The flavor is amazing with a big malty caramel tone backed with a bit of boozy warmth, some pine and grapefruit resin, and an assertive oak-ed floral hop tone. Very nuanced, deep and lovely. Lots of hop depth but also loads of malt characteristic. Sticky hoppy oak caramel notes. Warming alcohol finish and more hops.

2013 bottle, pours a dark reddish caramel color with a 1" white head. Nose is burnt sugar, pine, caramel, leather, spruce. It’s a little hot, but the ABV is pretty high so...to be expected. This is a well balance, very smooth beer.

Bottle sample at Stone tasting at Beer&Beyond shop. Pours almost clear red-brown with a nice head and good lacing. Aroma - piney hops, malts, caramel and alcohol. Sweet with flavors of fruits, licorice, malts and long lasting strong hoppy bitterness, alcohol is quite noticeable. Medium-full bodied.

On tap, clear deep orange-brown hue w/ medium beige head. Moderate sweet citrus hop aromas. Initial flavor is moderate sweet w/ a bold bitter finish of long duration. Tastes are pine, caramel, apple, and tangerine. Big bodied, average carbonation, and a dry finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This Ale is so thick and full of flavor, I want to pour it on my pancakes. Tastes of caramel and a lemony hop tartness. A medium off-white head gives to a ruby-orange hued body. Nice lacing. One of my new favorites. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a burnt amber color with a khaki head and beautiful lacing. . Big hop, caramel, malt and toffee aroma with wood undertones. Big hop, malt, caramel, toffee, raisin, plum, pine and alcohol flavors. Medium full body with a thick, syrup like mouth feel. Bitter but other flavors tone it down. Malt and caramel finish. A very big beer.

November 25, 2013 - on tap at Town Hall Lanes. Not sure how I have never rated this before, but here goes. It was dark in the bar, but appearance looked to be a light brown with nice head that lasted. Aroma was big malt and hops, with some dark fruit that came out as it warmed. Taste was sticky sweet caramel, dark fruit, alcohol and piney bitter finish. Nice thick body that was smooth.

Poured from a bomber into a pint glass. Deep reddish brown color, one inch head. Nice soft aroma of fresh hops and citrus. Flavor belies the aroma, however. It is strongly malty with an intense bitter finish. "Harsh" might be the most suitable word here. None of the citrus from the aroma makes its way into the flavor. The abv is everywhere and unavoidable. Still, fairly smooth for 11%, and what saves this beer. Drink two arrogant bastards instead. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a deep reddish brown with a thin whitish head. Sweet aroma. Slightly sweet taste with a bitter finish. Much smoother than expected. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap @ Collins Pub. Pours dark reddish amber with thin creamy white head. Aroma is syrupy sweet malt, with pale molasses and earthy oaky undertones. Taste is big roasty amber malt, thick and syrupy, followed by sharply bitter hop finish with notes of pine and grass. Sizable ABV is obvious and impossible to ignore. One goes a long way. Just a monster beer by any measure.

Brown with a hint of Amber. White head that dissipates quickly. Strong taste of booze and malt. Citrus including bitter grapefruit. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours brown with red hues and an off-white head. Smells caramel, bready, slight spruce. Has a really strong flavor, hot. Borderline barley-wine in my opinion. Sweet malts with a strong, lingering bitterness to it. Good.

Bottle from Bert’s 
Pours a brilliantly clear deep copper color with a decent sized off white head that shows moderate retention and lace. Aromas of pine resin and grapefruit pith atop brown sugary caramel and hints of cheery and toffee. The flavor is heavy on the pine, resin and brown sugar. Slight warming alcohol warns of the abv. Caramel, toffee, light plum and prune round out the flavor. Assertive hop bitterness but never harsh. Medium to thick body with a light to moderate level of carbonation and a sweet slick almost syrupy mouthfeel. Very nice strong ale, I enjoyed sipping on this for most of the night.

Draft, Dark amber color with a nice white head. Aroma is sweet with hints of dark fruit and hops. Sticky sweet bitterness lingers for a while. Great beer. Seems a bit smoother than the regular Bastard.

On tap @ Tap25. Cloudy, orange with disappearing head. Very, very light smells of fruit and hops. Tastes of malty booziness, sweet, but finishes with a bitter aftertaste. Seems like a complex beer, changing as it warmed up, but I still wonder if Arrogant Bastard is better than this. A little more malt with an alcohol bite. Would love to try them together.
On tap at the brewery, pours amber with low head, aroma is rich roast and pine hops, taste is bold bitter roast, delisious.
Pours a dark amber. Thin off white head. Lots of maltiness. Somewhat bitter. Some aroma of dark fruits. Flavor is somewhat bland. Alcoholic.

Metallic and boozy aromas with a Chinook hop aroma, though muted by the boozy notes on the aroma. Flavor is like a under-aged barley wine but a bit thinner on the palate than the traditional American Barleywine. Finish is slightly bitter and alcoholic. Overrated at 100pts.
Pours a hazy orange with some sediment. Has a strong malt, butterscotch, and hops. Taste is complex with hints of rum and strong fruity malt and prune juice flavor. Bitter malt and hop aftertaste.
